body:
> Also the {str:concat("Hello ","!")} renders as Hello ! (correctly) but the {str:concat("Hello '","!")} as Hello '","!.

You're right that there is a bug in the parser - if a virtual method parameter contains a string literal with nested literal separator, such as `"Hello '"`.

> I use the following example {str:builder('Qute').append("is").append("cool!")} and it renders as Quteisisiscool!cool!cool!

I wasn't able to reproduce this one.

> I think this is a problem in all str functions, or in general where Strings are used and apostrophe ' is included. (I think it happens in eval too.)

It's a general problem and I'm working on a fix.

issue.title: Qute: fix nested literal separator in a virtual method parameter
issue.body:
- fix the parser if a virtual method parameter contains a string literal with nested literal separator, such as "Hello '"
- fixes #47092

body:
> > > I use the following example {str:builder('Qute').append("is").append("cool!")} and it renders as Quteisisiscool!cool!cool!
> 
> > I wasn't able to reproduce this one.
> 
> [@gbourant](https://github.com/gbourant) could you prepare a reproducer for this one?

In my reproducer it works as expected, I'll try to find out why it does not in my project.

I was able to reproduce it [here](https://github.com/gbourant/qute-append-bug) and it's kind of funny :)
 
If a template exists (even if it's not used, in the my example it's not used) but it's content is `{str:builder('Hello').append("error")}`, the `/hello` endpoint which does not use the template, returns `Quteisisiscool!cool!cool!`.

> I was able to reproduce it [here](https://github.com/gbourant/qute-append-bug) and it's kind of funny :)

This is not funny but scary ðŸ‘€ . I'll take a look.

> If a template exists (even if it's not used, in the my example it's not used) but it's content is `{str:builder('Hello').append("error")}`, the `/hello` endpoint which does not use the template, returns `Quteisisiscool!cool!cool!`.

BTW the template file is not needed to reproduce the problem.

> > I was able to reproduce it [here](https://github.com/gbourant/qute-append-bug) and it's kind of funny :)
> 
> This is not funny but scary ðŸ‘€ . I'll take a look.
> 
> > If a template exists (even if it's not used, in the my example it's not used) but it's content is `{str:builder('Hello').append("error")}`, the `/hello` endpoint which does not use the template, returns `Quteisisiscool!cool!cool!`.
> 
> BTW the template file is not needed to reproduce the problem.

Actually, you were right and I found the problem! When a template file exists then we do generate a `ValueResolver` for `StringBuilder` (because it's used in a namespace expression that is covered by a template extension method and hence the type info is available).

But the generated resolver calls all `append()` methods that match the given param type (`String` in this particular case) ðŸ¤¦ .

@gbourant https://github.com/quarkusio/quarkus/pull/47100/commits/2e50b88ee03ab34e27209d8ea18522e715232846 should fix the problem. It would be great if you could test your app with the proposed fix...
Yeap, I tried your branch and both of the reported issues work as expected.
